medium_description_en: Predicts risk of pathologic fracture in patients with long bone metastasis.
instructions_en: Use in patients with known long bone metastasis. Do not use if history of fracture or previous irradiation.

seo.meta_description_en: Mirels’ Criteria for Prophylactic Fixation predicts risk of pathologic fracture in patients with long bone metastasis.
seo.keywords_en: Mirel, mirel’s, mirels, mirel criteria, Harrington, long bone, bone mets, bony mets, prophylactic fixation, IF, pathologic fracture, fracture, criteria

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients with known long bone metastasis, without history of fracture or previous irradiation.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Shown to have greater variability in agreement when scored by medical and radiation oncologists, to whom these patients are most likely to present.
  • Can only be used to predict fracture risk in long bones (i.e., not in vertebral mets).
  • Better validated than the earlier Harrington Criteria.
  • While the original paper describes the size of the lesion as a percentage of the cortex, in practice it is classified as a percentage of the width (diameter) of the bone at that level.
  • Predicts fracture risk in the 6 months after radiotherapy, which may not be relevant for many patients (i.e., if no plans for radiotherapy and/or short life expectancy).

next_steps.advice_en: In addition to Mirels’ Criteria, consider patient-specific factors such as comorbidities, predicted survival, other sites of disease, activity level, and bone mineral density when deciding whether or not to recommend prophylactic fixation.

creator_info.about_en: Hilton Mirels, MD, is an orthopaedic surgeon and has been in practice for almost 40 years. He completed his training at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, South Africa. Dr. Mirels is best known for his eponymous criteria for long bone fracture.
